description.narrative:
PASS was established in 2000 to stimulate investment and growth in commercial agriculture and related sectors by providing business development and financial services to small and medium agribusinesses, to stimulate investments and promote growth of commercial agri-businesses in Tanzania, for enhanced inclusive economic growth and poverty reduction.
As such, the target group is mainly small agribusinesses who are unable to get a commercial bank as they lack collateral, information and knowledge on how to develop business plans or how to apply for a bank loan. PASS also collaborates with medium seized businesses who's activities have positive effects on the main target group such as smallholder farmers or sub-contractors.
PASS charges the banks a fee of 3-4 % depending on the guarantee provided, a cost which is not affecting the client. The reasons being sustainability and avoidance of market distortions. Instead, PASS can assist the clients in comparing banks and the collaboration also at times reduces the interests rates as banks see a lowered risk.
Swedish collaboration with PASS is guided by the Strategy for Sweden's International Development Cooperation in Tanzania with the overall goal "To contribute to conditions for sustainable growth in Tanzania that provide people living in poverty with better opportunities to support themselves by obtaining work and starting and running productive businesses”.
In addition, the collaboration with PASS is regarded as a Swedish contribution to the implementation of Tanzania’s Five Year Development Plan II and Vision 2025, of increased agribusinesses, industrialization, and economic development, along with other Swedish partners such as FSDT, AMDT, TAHA, REA, and SIDO and COSTECH.
Sweden views PASS as a highly relevant partner in its role as an intermediary who understands both the banks and the agribusinesses, assists in making unbankable clients bankable, lowers the risk for both banks and clients, and contributes to unleashing the potential of Tanzanian agribusinesses and economic development. Also, PASS contributes to banks' increased knowledge about the agriculture sector and thereby, addresses market failures and information asymmetries.
The collaboration with Sweden will contribute to expanding PASS's guarantee volume, which means that PASS can extend more guarantees. The advantage for PASS is extended volume meaning that more businesses will, potentially, qualify as borrowers and / or for larger guarantee amounts, which will not only enhance the results and outreach of PASS, it will also provide larger revenues in terms of fees from collaborating Banks, which will make PASS more financially sustainable.
Sweden will, extend a guarantee of 20 MUSD to complement PASS’s current guarantee scheme to support bank’s lending to clients in the agriculture sector. Sweden’s guarantee is not cash funded, but a paper guarantee backed by the government of Sweden (rated AAA by Fitch, S&P and Moody’s) therefore normally considered a zero-risk in the balance sheet of banks. The guarantee is a portfolio guarantee, Sweden will therefore not be involved in each single transaction but cover 60% of the guarantees provided by PASS who in turn covers up to 60% (80% for women owned businesses) of the lending bank’s risk. Risk sharing with PASS and the banks is important to assure a good quality portfolio.
PASS will be able to work with the banks as before and will always be the fronting entity towards the banks, but where the intention is that each client will be guaranteed by a combination of the PASS guarantee and the guarantee from Sweden. Any claims made by the banks will be made to PASS who in turn will claim Sweden for its share of the guarantee.
For its guarantees, Sida charges an upfront administration fee (origination fee) and a fee for its expected loss expressed as an annual utilization fee on the outstanding guarantee amount (utilization fee). For the PASS guarantee, Sida has assigned the Swedish National Debt Office to calculate the expected loss and necessary subsidy for the guarantee given the utilization fee of 1.5% p.a. on outstanding guarantee amount paid for by PASS. Expected loss is calculated to USD 1 948 906 and the utilization fee received to USD 860 890. The net amount i.e. USD 1 088 016 represents the subsidy for the expected loss which calculated to Swedish Kronor with an exchange rate of SEK 8.00 / USD equals SEK 8 704 128 (to be paid to Sida's premium reserv accout with the Swedish National Debt Office). Sida’s administrative costs for origination and management of the guarantee throughout the life of the guarantee amounts to SEK 1 050 000. This cost is entirely subsidized (paid to Sida's RTA-account). The total subsidy amount thus equals to SEK 9 754 128 (expected loss: 8 704 128 plus administrative costs: 1 050 000). The subsidy is justified since guaranteed banks wouldn't accept PASS's guarantee fees if Sida's fees would have been included. The fee paid by PASS (utilization fee of 1,5% p.a.) is set at such level whereby it is expected not to jeoperdize PASS's profitability.
Sweden seeks to support local ownership and alignment and prefers not to take an active role in boards and governing bodies, but rather be focused on its role as a donor and not implementer. Therefore, Sweden does not see it as necessary to participate in either the Board of Trustees or the Founders Committee. As long as Denmark is on the committee, the donors are represented.
However, Swedish development cooperation is guided by Swedish laws, regulations, and policies etc. As such, Sweden, through the Embassy in Tanzania, is required to adhere to certain policy aspects as well as conditions for implementation. As such, Sweden is required to approve strategies, annual business plans and budgets, as well as reports as explained below.
The main guiding principles that are required to be addressed during partnership are: Environment and climate change, gender equality, and poverty reduction. As such, PASS is required to undertake a simplified environmental assessment and Sweden will support PASS in formulating improved definitions on target groups and 3-4 results with indicators that allow monitoring of progress related to poverty reduction i.e. jobs and incomes, as part of the new strategy development. A gender analysis is also needed, but could be undertaken as part of the new strategy development.
Since Sweden do not have the full information of the new strategy and direction of PASS, as a risk mitigation measure Sweden have included a caveat in the agreement regarding the completion of the new strategy from 2018. That is, PASS will have access to the guarantee prior to finalization of the new strategy along with a more full fledged result framework for guidance and monitoring up to one year after signing of the Guarantee Agreement. If the new strategy is not in place by then, we have the right to terminate the Guarantee Agreement. This way, Sweden will ensure that the operations of PASS, also in the future, are in line with principles for Swedish development cooperation, strategy in Tanzania and fulfill requirements of quality and measurable results.
Sweden will provide financial TA-support to the drafting process of the strategy, RBM as well as gender and environment assessments (Decision on contibution 2017/20). The procurement of these services can be from Embassy of Sweden but the ownership has to lie with PASS.

Private Agricultural Sector Support Trust - PASS arbetar med affärsutveckling och tillhandahåller finansiella tjänster åt små lantbrukare samt små- och medelstora entreprenörer inom jordbrukssektorn i Tanzania. PASS grundades av Danmarks tillsammans med Tanzanias regering för att stimulera investeringar och öka tillväxten i jordbrukssektorn som försörjer en majoritet av Tanzanias befolkning, framförallt de som lever i fattigdom, och för att på så sätt stödja fattigdomsminskning och ekonomisk utveckling. Idag karaktäriseras sektorn av låg tillväxt, låga inkomster, låg produktivitet och bristfällig infrastruktur. En av de främsta orsakerna till detta är begränsad tillgång till finansiella tjänster generellt och för jordbrukssektion specifikt.
PASSs fokus är således att stödja äffärsutveckling och bidra med finansiella tjänster till framförallt små lantbrukare, företagare och kooperativ. De agerar som en länk mellan låntagare och långivare (banker) och förbättrar låntagares lånevillkor och stödjer affärsplansutveckling. De erbjuder bland annat att stå som garant i de fall låntagaren saknar nödvändig säkerhet för kommersiella banklån, vilket de flesta av PASS klienter gör givet målgruppen. Till liten del stödjer de även medelstora företag om deras verksamhet har positiv påverkan på mikro och små företag såsom underleverantörer.
PASS tar en avgift från banken på 3-4 % beroende på garantityp, vilket inte påverkar klientens ränta. Räntan är fortfarande marknadsmässigt, för att vara hållbar och ej marknadsstörande, men reduceras i vissa fall då banken ser minskad risk tack vare PASSs stöd till klienten. PASS stödjer även klienter att jämföra banker för att hitta mer förmånliga villkor.
PASS garanti täcker upp till 80% av den totala lånesumman för kvinnliga låntagare och upp till 60% för manliga låntagare.
Enligt banker i Tanzania har samarbetet med PASS bidragit till en ökat aptit för utlåning till små entreprenörer inom jordbrukssektorn, en grupp som tidigare ansetts ha för hög riskprofil. Samarbetet har även resulterat i en minskad risk för banker, en ökad medvetenhet om finansiella tjänster hos lantbrukare och entreprenörer, samt förbättrat bankernas kunskap om utlåning till jordbrukssektorn.
Hittills har PASS garanterat lån som totalt uppgår till ett värde över Tsh 300 miljarder (ca MUSD 135) genom ett tiotal olika banker med en återbetalningsgrad på ca 98 %. PASS nätverk är omfattande och innebär att man också når klienter i landets mest avlägsna områden, där banker sällan är representerade och på så sätt når utsatta och exkluderade grupper.
Sidas garantiinstrument avses att användas för insatsens genomförande i enlighet med förordningen om finansiering av utvecklingslån och garantier för utvecklingssamarbete (SFS 2009:320) samt förordning om utlåning och garantier (SFS 2011:211). Garantin ämnar vara ett komplement till PASS garantin som genom att dess maximala garantivolym uppnåtts, nu erbjuds utökad garantivolym vilket i sin tur möjliggör ökad utlåning från banker som har avtal med och garanteras av PASS. Insatsen regleras genom ett mellan Sida och PASS undertecknat garantiavtal. Sådant avtal bygger inte på Sidas avtalsmallar utan har utarbetats av L&G i samråd med JUR och Ambassaden. L&G har konsulterat Sidas revisionsrådgivare vad gäller avtalets revisionsvillkor.
Samarbetet mellan Sverige och PASS tillåter PASS totala garantivolym att expandera. Den större garantivolymen leder till att PASS kan utfärda fler och större garantier till kvalificerade små lantbrukare och entreprenörer. En större garantivolym kommer att bidra till bättre resultat och samtidigt förbättra PASS finansiella ställning då riskdelningsavgiften som bankerna betalar förväntas att öka, och PASS blir mer finansiellt hållbara.
Sida kommer att utfärda en svensk statsgaranti om 20 miljoner USD för att komplettera PASS nuvarande cash-garanti som stödjer bankernas utlåning till jordburkssektorn. En svensk statsgaranti är en pappersgaranti med den svenska staten (AAA av Fitch, S&P och Moody’s) som garant och garantin bedöms vanligtvis som riskfri i bankernas balansräkning.
I samarbetet med bankerna kommer PASS alltid att vara den frontande organisationen, och Sverige står bakom. Intentionen är att alla klienter kommer att garanteras av en kombination av PASS cash-garanti och en svensk pappersgaranti. Där alla betalningskrav från bankerna kommer till PASS, som i sin tur kräver Sverige på 60 % den garanterade summan.
Då PASS verksamhet ämnar bidra till inkluderande ekonomisk utveckling anses den föreslagna insatsen vara relevant för det övergripande målet i Resultatstrategin för Sveriges internationella bistånd i Tanzania 2013 – 2019 och mer specifikt resultat 2.3 ”Ökade möjligheter för kvinnor och unga att starta och driva produktiva företag”. Insatsen bidrar även till att uppfylla resultat 1.2 ”Utvecklade marknader i jordbruksproduktionen med ambitionen att fler fattiga människor, framförallt kvinnor, har fått arbetet och ökade inkomster.
Det finns potential till samordning och synergier med andra svenskt stödda insatser i Tanzania så som Financial Sector Deepening Trust (FSDT), Tanzania Horticultural Association (TAHA), Agricultural Markets Development Trust (AMDT), COSTECH/SIDO, UNDAP II och Coffee Farmers Alliances Tanzania (CFAT). Kopplingen till dessa kan stärkas med PASS som partnerorganisation eller att PASS går in som lånegarant i någon eller några av de angivna insatserna. Det finns ytterligare synergier inom ramen för förnybar energi då PASS är lämpade för att facilitera utlåning till energiinvesteringar i jordbrukssektorn.
Som del i programhantering stödjer Sverige PASS i framtagandet av ny strategi 2018-2022 (Beslut om stöd till strategiutveckling PASS, 20/2017) med fokus på fattigdomsminskning och ekonomisk utveckling. Som del i denna process kommer Sverige även stödja arbete med utvecklande av resultatramverk för förbättrad rapportering av inkomster och jobb, samt miljö och genderintegrering för att säkerställa fokus på och underlätta rapportering av inkluderande ekonomisk utveckling.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The guarantee quarterly reports and the developmental results narrative report indicates a general increase of Banks’ appetite to lend in Agricultural projects. The Swedish re-guarantee has supported PASS to have a tremendous growth of its portfolio with increase in number of beneficiaries and high impact on poverty. As a result of Swedish complementary guaranteee, partner banks to lend to agribusiness has increased resulting to increase a leverage from 1:1 to 1:3 with Credit Guarantee Fund. The following are examples of results based on core PASS's business indicators: • Business Developement Services: In the year 2018, PASS reported about 15,446 of its business plans submitted to banks • Guaratees: The total credit accommodation granted to agribusiness sector under PASS Guarantee Scheme reached TZS 217.9 Billion in the year 2018, against a corresponding total of TZS 184.1 Billion in 2017. • Beneficiaries: In 2018, 196,873 agri-business enterprises used PASS services, creating 387,804 employments opportunities. The agribusiness enterprises referred to includes large enterprises, farmer groups/associations and SACCOS, companies as well as individuals involved in agricultural activities • Total guarantees committed was TZS 103 billion (approx. USD 45 million) against paid-up guarantee claims of TZS 5.3 billion (approx. USD 2.3 million) – 5.14% Sweden has further supported PASS with: - a) Training and couching workshops on development and operationalization of Gender Policy and action plans b) Provided Bilateral Associate Expert (BAE) to support PASS on technical advice and developemmnt of policy an action plan on social and environmental sustainability in compliance with green growth. The Embassy's comments from previous year’s reports were implemented to a large extent and the reporting has improved. PASS has also a parallel report to the Public which shows the general picture and progress of and the outcome and the general public awareness of the trust's role in the economy.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
